headline: Why Lockheed Martin (LMT) Shares Are Plunging Today
summary: Shares of security and Aerospace company Lockheed Martin (NYSE:LMT) fell 5.1% in the afternoon session after the U.S. Air Force significantly cut its request for F-35 fighter jets. The Air Force, Lockheed's largest customer, reduced its forecasted order from 48 planes to 24. This unexpected cut raises concerns about future revenue growth from the F-35 line, and may prompt investors to reassess their expectations.

headline: Nvidia comments rally quantum stocks, Pentagon to cut jet order
summary: Yahoo Finance host Madison Mills tracks today's top moving stocks and biggest market stories in this Market Minute, including the stock gains in quantum computing companies D-Wave Quantum (QBTS), Rigetti Computing (RGTI), and IonQ (IONQ) upon Nvidia (NVDA) CEO Jensen Huang's positive comments on the technology, and US defense officials reportedly cutting their order for F-35 jets from Lockheed Martin (LMT). Stay up to date on the latest market action, minute-by-minute, with Yahoo Finance's Market Minute.

headline: Lockheed Martin Stock Plunges on F-35 Orders. It Might Be An Overreaction.
summary: Lockheed stock fell 5.5% to $450.96 in early trading, while the  and the  were flat.  The drop came after Bloomberg reported that the Air Force is asking for 24 F-35 fighter jets this year, down from 48 in 2024.  Lockheed Martin and the Defense Department didn’t immediately respond to requests for comment.

headline: The Pentagon to order fewer F-35s than planned
summary: In a move towards austerity, the Pentagon has just halved its next order of F-35s for the US Air Force. Only 24 fighter jets will be delivered out of the 48 initially planned by Congress. Bloomberg...

headline: Pentagon slashes in half its request for Air Force F-35s, Bloomberg News reports
summary: A U.S. Defense Department procurement request document sent to Capitol Hill this week asked for 24 of the planes, down from 48 that were forecast last year, the report said.  Lockheed Martin and the Department of Defense did not respond to requests for comment outside regular business hours.
